title: What is the purpose of the <picture> element?
content: Explain how <picture> can be used to serve different images for different screen sizes.
explanation: <picture> allows multiple <source> elements with media queries or type attributes, letting the browser choose the best image based on device resolution or format.
sampleAnswers: <picture> allows multiple <source> elements with media queries or type attributes, letting the browser choose the best image based on device resolution or format.

title: What is the difference between <figure> and <figcaption>?
explanation: <figure> wraps content like images, charts, or diagrams; <figcaption> provides a caption for that content. Together, they semantically describe media.
sampleAnswers: <figure> wraps content like images, charts, or diagrams; <figcaption> provides a caption for that content. Together, they semantically describe media.

title: Explain the difference between <mark> and <em>.
content: When should you use <mark> instead of <em>?
explanation: <mark> highlights text for reference or search relevance, <em> emphasizes text semantically, usually changing voice or importance for accessibility.
sampleAnswers: <mark> highlights text for reference or search relevance, <em> emphasizes text semantically, usually changing voice or importance for accessibility.

title: What are data-* attributes in HTML?
content: Explain their purpose and how to access them via JavaScript.
explanation: data-* attributes store custom data on elements. Access in JS via element.dataset.key. Example: <div data-user-id='123'> and JS: element.dataset.userId.
sampleAnswers: data-* attributes store custom data on elements. Access in JS via element.dataset.key. Example: <div data-user-id='123'> and JS: element.dataset.userId.

title: Explain the difference between <nav> and <header>.
content: When should each be used in HTML5?
explanation: <header> defines introductory content or a site header, <nav> contains navigation links. Header can have nav inside it.
sampleAnswers: <header> defines introductory content or a site header, <nav> contains navigation links. Header can have nav inside it.

title: How do you use the <details> and <summary> elements?
content: Explain with an example how users can toggle content visibility.
explanation:
Click to expand

Hidden content

allows toggling visibility of content without JavaScript.
sampleAnswers:
Click to expand

Hidden content

allows toggling visibility of content without JavaScript.

title: Explain the use of the <progress> element.
explanation: <progress> shows task completion progress, <meter> represents a scalar measurement like disk usage. Both provide semantic feedback to users.
sampleAnswers: <progress> shows task completion progress, <meter> represents a scalar measurement like disk usage. Both provide semantic feedback to users.

title: How does the <template> element work?
content: Explain its use and why it doesn't render content immediately.
explanation: <template> holds HTML that isn't rendered immediately. JS can clone its content and insert it into the DOM dynamically for efficient rendering.
sampleAnswers: <template> holds HTML that isn't rendered immediately. JS can clone its content and insert it into the DOM dynamically for efficient rendering.

title: What are ARIA roles in HTML?
content: How do ARIA attributes improve accessibility?
explanation: ARIA roles like role='button' or aria-label provide semantic meaning to assistive technologies, improving accessibility for screen readers.
sampleAnswers: ARIA roles like role='button' or aria-label provide semantic meaning to assistive technologies, improving accessibility for screen readers.

title: What is the difference between <base> and <link> tags?
explanation: sets a base URL for relative links, affecting , ,
sampleAnswers: sets a base URL for relative links, affecting , ,

title: Explain the use of <slot> in Web Components.
explanation: <slot> acts as a placeholder in a Web Component. The parent can inject custom content into it, enabling flexible content composition.
sampleAnswers: <slot> acts as a placeholder in a Web Component. The parent can inject custom content into it, enabling flexible content composition.

title: What is the difference between <bdo> and <dir>?
content: Explain how <bdo> changes text direction and what <dir> does historically.
explanation: <bdo dir='rtl'> forces text direction, <dir> was used for directories (deprecated). Use <ul> for modern lists instead of <dir>.
sampleAnswers: <bdo dir='rtl'> forces text direction, <dir> was used for directories (deprecated). Use <ul> for modern lists instead of <dir>.

title: How can you lazy-load images in HTML5?
explanation: delays loading images until they are about to enter the viewport, improving page performance.
sampleAnswers: delays loading images until they are about to enter the viewport, improving page performance.

title: Explain the difference between <main> and <article>.
content: When should each be used in HTML5?
explanation: <main> represents the primary content of a page, <article> represents a self-contained piece of content that could be reused independently (e.g., blog post).
sampleAnswers: <main> represents the primary content of a page, <article> represents a self-contained piece of content that could be reused independently (e.g., blog post).

title: What is the difference between <output> and <progress>?
content: Explain the semantic use cases for <output> vs <progress> in forms.
explanation: <output> displays the result of a calculation or user action, <progress> shows task completion progress. Output is for dynamic content, progress is for status indication.
sampleAnswers: <output> displays the result of a calculation or user action, <progress> shows task completion progress. Output is for dynamic content, progress is for status indication.
